Row.Text: Gold now flows from every field and every workshop, its seductive sparkle at the corner of every eye. It will bolster the economy and gild the thrones of the nobles, while local artisans prepare to serve the world's ever-growing appetite for crafts of beauty.

Every season come the rains, and an abundance of water swelling the rivers and nourishing the fields. But for the rest of the year, the earth grows so dry it cracks and crops die. With wells deep enough to capture the rains, life could be preserved even when the dust chokes out the sun.
The people tour the wells, exploring their staircases and murmuring about the wisdom of their leader.
Have a Stepwell in every Settlement within {1_turn_timer}.
The Mughal capital has fallen, but its people continue to fight. A mutiny against just rule!
The invaders have breached the walls and flooded into the capital, demanding surrender. But the people will not lay down their arms until they reclaim their home. All glory to the martyrs!

The laying of the Eiffel Tower's foundation brings celebration, but also controversy. A committee of local artists protests the monument, claiming it will overshadow the city's other masterpieces. Passionate arguments from the tower's backers about the potential for unparalleled profits don't seem to sway them.
A new fount of oil has been discovered near the capital, on land owned by one of the region's wealthy families. But drilling rights quickly fall into dispute.
Share profits in exchange for drilling rights.
Force them to sell the land.

A hero returns from the battlefield, elephant drenched with blood and sweat. The cheering people raise him onto their shoulders, claiming he is the legendary hero Naresuan from centuries past, now reborn. Looking on, the nobles grumble to see this celebration of a commoner.
The ironclad emerges victorious after a fierce battle at sea. Her triumph captures the hearts of the people, all of whom cannot get enough of their new metal hero.
Hire a designer to create a clothing line.
The opera's leading lady has gone missing under mysterious circumstances. Rumors spread of organ music drifting from the depths below the stage.
Let the opera have its ghosts.
Pamphlets promising the location of hidden treasures enter wide circulation. It seems there is much plentitude to be unearthed in the world, perhaps more than there is room to store.
These treasures must find a new home.

The museum's grand opening draws crowds, long lines forming to see the treasures of the wider world. The collection inspires awe and wonderment about the peoples and places who originated such artifacts, though many display cases stand empty, awaiting new additions.
The citrus crop has been devastated by a recent tornado, scattering fruit, pulp, and pith beneath the feet of despairing farmers. Many wonder when, if ever, they will financially recover.
Enrich the soil with imported fertilizer.
Direct more workers to the farms.
A cuirassier contemplates a confection: a crisp croissant. Captivated, his comrades call the captain to confess their cravings for some cache of creature comforts for their company.
A strange disease runs rampant among the people of the tropics. Some say in ancient times, such illness was treated with quinine, but others insist that surely there must be more modern solutions.
The spread of quinine has halted the tropical illness that once ravaged the populace. It stands as a lesson from the past, emphasizing the importance of preserving ancestral knowledge.
Working swiftly in the laboratory, doctors synthesize a new treatment for the tropical disease afflicting the population. The epidemic shrinks away in the light of new science, and citizens rejoice.

Increasingly disturbing reports from the front make their way to popular newspapers. Politicians are critical of information they find too extreme for public consumption, but journalists insist that readers deserve to know the realities of war.
Implement policy to tone down violent details.

A series of articles in prominent newspapers are unsparing in their critiques of local industry and business practices. The editor of one major newspaper clashes with a business owner who insists he is the victim of defamation.
Journalism must speak truth to power.
The newspapers should expand their legal teams.
The technology of the steam engine spurs the development of air compressors. Using this invention, an engineer is inspired to craft a caisson to enable work below the water level.
The caisson is a success, and the port's construction opens new opportunities for seafaring exploits. However, workers emerge from the depths grappling with symptoms of a mysterious illness.
The flooded mine is successfully conquered by the caisson, enabling miners to work beneath the water table. However, their work seems to be making them sick in ways no one is able to explain.
Improve a Coal, Silver, or Gold Resource within {1_turn_timer}.

Doctors investigate the illness plaguing the caisson workers, and find it is caused by decompression. Further research is needed to combat and treat the syndrome, but businesses are impatient for more caisson projects.
There are reports of a potential bomb in a local home, a family waking in the night to a devastating bang. The culprit, however, turns out to be a can of beans that exploded.

As the modern age launches the people into the future, ancient legends begin to resurface, mythic tales of the empire's origins. Many look to these works to remind themselves of their roots, drawing lessons that are not always accurate, but meaningful nonetheless.
The truth behind these texts must be understood.

People have started seeing things in the night sky over the airfield. Reports abound of mysterious distant lights that swim and sway through the dark in illogical patterns. The military denies involvement.
The air force should guard its secrets.
People are being carried away by imagination.
Fighter pilots, too, are now seeing strange lights over the airfield, and the phenomenon remains unexplained. The endorsement of airmen only emboldens popular theories on what might be out there.
Have the troops monitor the airspace.

Divebomber pilots claim to have seen mysterious lights over the airfield, the same ones that have lit afire the imaginations of local sky-watchers. The pilots, however, say all signs point to an enemy incursion.

A new heavy bomber is unveiled to local air force pilots, and during its test flights, onlookers see a distinctive pattern of lights. It would appear that all along, the night sky phenomenon was caused by secret military technology, not UFOs.
Announce the bomber and dispel the myths.
Protect local storytelling along with military secrets.
In the hands of gifted stonecutters, the marble carves like butter, and glows like flesh.
Conserve it for the most beautiful tombs.
A strange lump on the horizon that seems to be an island reveals itself to be an entirely new continent as ships draw closer. The captain puzzles over his outdated map.

People living near the railroad tracks say that the noise of trains at all hours is disrupting their sleep. They plead for a reduction in overnight trains, but the impact on goods transportation would be deeply felt.
Production must come first for now.
Wise folk insist that humans are but guests in this world. But in the tropics, falling coconuts have become a menace, and quite a few people have been knocked out by the inevitability of nature.
Nature has a right to retaliate.
Like a heartbeat, the rhythm of drums signals the beginning of the community work day. The bright-eyed civilians gather toward a common goal.
The communal cleaning projects are hard work indeed, but they provide valuable opportunities for the youth to connect with the elders, and to learn their ways.
The young should learn basket weaving.

After one too many work absences, a young citizen is brought before the tribunal. He insists he has been caring for a sick parent, although councillors claim it's an excuse he's used time and time again to evade his share of the labor.

As Kabaka's Lake fills with water, the land begins to change, blooming with vibrant life. The transformation attracts new wild birds, inspiring artists and exciting naturalists with their novel chorus.
Wild birds make ideal artists' models.
Each new species should be catalogued.

Twin wonders of metal shine in the sun. The Statue of Liberty holds aloft her torch to the sea, while the Eiffel Tower is surrounded by admiring tourists. Just as Gustave Eiffel imagined, his architecture has become a beacon for the people's dreams.
The Statue of Liberty is the crown jewel of France's artistic achievements. Many take pride in her beauty, while others see the promise of prosperity in her burnished face.
May she invite wealth to these shores.

The tank engine rumbles across the battlefield like a moving fortress, and the earth trembles. Its thick armor is impervious to bullets. But with an immense bang, a charge from an AT gun pierces the tank's hull, sending soldiers running from the smoking cloud.
Invest in strengthening existing AT units.

The local stepwell is always running low, and the farmers who visit it often end up in debates. A deeper well would better support the local farms and increase their yields, but a more decorative one might become a tourist attraction, bringing prosperity with it.
The industry must have more water.
Curators argue over the next exhibit to be installed in the Hermitage. One says the nature of the building lends itself to Renaissance frescoes. The other pushes for Romantic paintings instead.

The state's consolidation of private rail companies into the Staatseisenbahn allows for tighter control over its function and potential profit. Public advocates say lower freight service costs would boost the economy, but expanded railways will make new territories rapidly accessible.
Lower freight service costs for all.

The obschina population grows in community alongside its expanding farmland, and a recent census calls for the reallocation of certain plots. While the intention is to increase efficiency and food production for the whole community, not all families are happy with their new parcels.
Maximize efficiency to the benefit of all.
Hardworking families should decide their shares.

The destroyer’s guns fall silent, and the enemy submarine slips beneath the waves for the last time. Sailors watch its demise from the decks, knowing that their victory over the underwater threat will shift the world of naval warfare.
This information will be of great worth.
Now is the time for secrecy.
A naval captain invents a new kind of mortar that can fire lines of rope to troubled ships from shore. It will require the sacrifice of existing mortars, but he insists that many lives will be saved.
Mortars should be maintained as they are.
As the suffrage movement grows in popularity, it promises the upheaval of the known. People are clamoring for some message from their officials, and many say that history's lessons can light the way.
Now is the time for unity.
The past shows us change is necessary.

Muzibu Azaala Mpanga, the community's largest tomb, requires constant maintenance to preserve its traditional thatched roof. Local residents feel passionate about this work of care, and a few have even taken it upon themselves to organize an amateur labor collective.
Set up an official preservation team.
Leave it in the community's hands.
There is no question that gunpowder must be shipped somehow, but there are constant arguments among traders at the entrepot over who will bear the risk of storing their cargo close by.
Sugar, despite the risk of melting.
Coal, despite the potential for fires.

As the storm hits the entrepot, a small spark sets off the gunpowder. The ensuing blaze ignites the sugar stored in the room next door, and the entire stock blows, offering an unfortunate lesson in chemistry.

As the storm hits the entrepot, a stray spark lights up the gunpowder. The ivory shipment next door is damaged in the ensuing explosion, but the fire leaves curious designs on the surviving tusks, and the trader claims it as a new art form.
As the storm engulfs the entrepot, a spark sets off the gunpowder. Miraculously, the coal stored in the next room remains untouched. Handlers exhale a sigh of relief at a disaster averted.

Visitors come from far and wide to admire Muzibu Azaala Mpanga, making innkeepers work overtime to accommodate the crowds. Many also wish to see the nearby lake's unique wildlife, attending tours arranged by preservationists.
Limit foot traffic in the lake's ecosystem.
The capital's radio station has an open slot for a new program. The station manager wants more situational comedy, but the public requests a lonely hearts hour.

The national opera house's popular radio show is sponsored by a private oil company. Though broadcasters embrace this act of generosity in a time when there's little funding for the arts, listeners wonder what crude oil has to do with the world of opera.

From its opening day, the department store is filled with eager shoppers, thrilled to have so many goods available in a single space. Less thrilled are the local businesses, who worry that their specialized offerings will soon be overshadowed.
Local business owners are crucial to the community.
As the war ends, the Prussian people are hungry for something to celebrate their unity. But no one can agree on whether a holiday or a monument will better stand the test of time.

As the crowd cheers, Victoria's chariot races toward the future atop towering columns. Luminaries give speeches, children toss flowers, and musical celebrations last into the night. Prussia enters a new dawn – what will she accomplish next?
The fame of the Hermitage grows as swiftly as its collection of marvels and curios. The world recognizes Russia as a cultural powerhouse, thanks to the discerning eye of her ruler.
Invest in experts to care for the works.
On a lunch break, an enterprising ironworker shapes a length of spare wire into an innovative human model. It looks like the perfect form on which to hang a tailor's work.

Inspired by the ironworker's captivating model of a human figure, a shopkeeper tries to join the trend, crafting a mannequin of leather and displaying it in his shop window. Its odd lumps and uncanny visage, however, seem to frighten far more customers than it attracts.

Building on the ironworker's innovative wire mannequin, a renowned fashion designer makes his own attempt at creating a human figure of wax. His artistic eye deftly captures the form of his apprentice, and soon seamstresses and tailors from all over the city flock to purchase his mannequins.
An artist has produced a marble sculpture for the palace gardens, but none seem certain exactly what it depicts. Is it a human figure? Or a nest of snakes?
Meaning is more important than strict definition.

The increasingly popular landship attracts many proposals to improve its engine. Adapted tractor mechanics might add more power to its movement, but army engineers have been exploring tweaks in the name of speed.

The recent barrage of storms triggers a widescale movement to better understand such awesome phenomena, and new groups form to help cope with future disasters. A cluster of researchers argue that weather must be studied scientifically to protect people and infrastructure. Yet a small community of naturalists prefers to focus on humanitarian efforts in the wake of devastation, arguing that weather is inevitable and should be spiritually revered.
Weather is a scientific problem with structural solutions.
Disaster is humanity's lot, bringing people together in care.
Ash and screams fill the air as the volcano hurls lava down its slopes. Some run, others pray.

As the booming volcano calls down its rain of ash, the people scramble to evacuate. All except a few soot-streaked scientists, too reckless or intrepid, depending on who one asks, to forego an opportunity for study. Knowledge may mitigate future disasters, they say.
Look for evidence to aid future predictions.
Abandon the study and help the evacuation.
In the wake of the recent river flood, the drenched land grows fertile. One group leaves offerings to the river, believing the tragedies of the land are nature's will.
As the floods recede, specialists take samples of the waters and the new soil deposits they leave in their wake in the hopes of managing future flood events.

Amid a howling blizzard, a group of fearless naturalists heads out into the snow to celebrate nature's latest dazzling show of power. They believe it is their right to cope with disaster as it moves them, but the rescue unit that forges out to save them from death begs to differ.
All may dance in the brutal snows.
The reckless will be fined for endangerment.
The recent blizzard buries the local weather office, and scientists are unable to measure the snow depth. Enthusiastic citizens volunteer their own amateur measurements.
Dig the meteorologists out at once.
How exact do these measurements need to be?

The dust storm seems to speak with its own fell voice, and many who accept the sovereignty of nature over all things call it sacred. But those whose homes and buildings have been destroyed by the disaster might prefer a more practical approach.
Commission a book on the language of dust.
Listen to the voices of victims.

Scientists claim that the virulent dust storms are fed by contemporary farming methods. With the elimination of native grasses, they say, the topsoil no longer holds. Real estate brokers do not care for this logic.

Rural farmers have seen groups of tornado-watchers following the storms, dancing in circles. Though the behavior draws much rumor and quizzical inquiry, they do leave large donations to the impacted farms.
Ask the group to help rebuild.

A scientist compiles fifteen rules for forecasting tornados, but the communications office throws up a roadblock to distribution. It claims the word "tornado" will trigger public panic if spoken on broadcasts, and orders a ban on its use despite meteorologists' protests.

A naturalist group believing in the righteousness of disaster has published a new tome on the mysticism of lightning. Although scientists deride the book, its proceeds all go toward humanitarian recovery efforts.
If the book helps people, its substance matters not.
Such thinking is dangerous in the long term.

As thunder rattles the window panes and rain lashes the glass, meteorologists struggle to compose weather maps that can decode such powerful storm systems. More data is needed, and at a quicker tempo.
Create an observation network of civilian volunteers.

The aftermath of the hurricane leaves many streets flooded. As people shout for help from rooftops, a canoe suddenly appears…then another, and another. Members of a naturalist society have come to help the stranded citizens into their vessels, promising they will soon return for the rest.
Honor the society with an award.

A recent academic paper claims that hurricanes are caused by a phenomenon called the Coriolis effect. To study it, the paper's author clung to a tree trunk in high winds, waiting for the eye of the storm to prove his theory.
Issue a mandate on safety in science.

A group of naturalists starts a new radio station called Gaia's Rage, grown through listener support. Through their programming, they begin to educate the public about spiritual perspectives on weather and how citizens can help one another in the aftermath of disaster. As a publicly funded body, the group's broadcasts are still subject to state influence.
There is no harm in spiritual messages on nature.
Require the organization of humanitarian efforts on the broadcast.
A television program brings big news: weather systems have mysterious effects on radar readings. The implications of such predictive technology excite the scientific imagination.
Weather prediction will benefit civic life.
This new science will be useful to the military.
Pilgrims reach Thera just in time to see the explosion of fire and flame. They gather ash-covered survivors, wrapping them in blankets and sharing what little food they have.
Hold a ceremony to honor the dead.

Scientists investigate reports of strange weather around Kilimanjaro, and find glowing lava emerging from its mouth. Hastily setting up their equipment, they monitor the eruption from afar, watching in awe as molten rock flows down into the valley.
Take time to research an eruption warning system for locals.
Promptly share the recent findings far and wide.

Something called a "dandy horse" seems to be all the rage in {1_capital}, a mechanical riding horse with wheels, handles and a wooden plank for a seat. One propels it with one's feet, and its inventor claims it is capable of a speedy 10 miles an hour. A few injuries have occurred, of course...

The theatre is a familiar comfort in the wake of wartime's fading sounds, but a new play perplexes: two paupers stand on a black box stage, pacing back and forth between a lifeless tree, waiting for someone...
The people see one another as equals, and believe every voice has its values. All are represented, all may speak, and all, collectively, decide. It is a way forward for all of humanity, they say.
"A government of laws, and not of men." - John Adams
Free thought is given free reign.
Hearts unite around a single leading figure, an exemplar that does not rule over the people as much as represent the best of them. A monarch, but one who is the people's servant, admired by all.
"Men agree amongst themselves to submit to some man...voluntarily, on confidence to be protected by him against all others." - Thomas Hobbes
A vacuum cannot exist in the hearts of the people.
Monarchs see future benefits, where others fail.
Everyone can vote, just so long as they vote for the right people. They are given a curated list to choose from – democracy is too delicate to trust entirely to the people's will.
"We decide what is right. Never mind what other people think." - Lee Kwan Yew
There is no progress without stability.
The people have spoken! Any person who speaks against the people shall be silenced!

“Before mass leaders seize the power to fit reality to their lies, their propaganda is marked by its extreme contempt for facts as such, for in their opinion fact depends entirely on the power of man who can fabricate it." - Hannah Arendt
Pride in the nation means pride in its defenders.
Patriotism must be felt by all. Or else.
The roar of the crowd. Forever.
Monarchies rule by destiny, unchanged and unchanging.
"I shall never, under any circumstances, agree to a representative form of government because I consider it harmful to the people whom God has entrusted to my care." - Tsar Nicholas II
Have 3 Commanders with a Commendation within {1_turn_timer}.
For the crown! May it live forever.
The past drives the future. Forever.
The nation, only the nation, all for the nation.
"Never before have the peoples thirsted for authority, direction, order, as they do now." - Benito Mussolini
History is a struggle for dominance.
Democracy lies at the heart of any true socialism.
"Democracy is indispensable to the working class, because only through the exercise of its democratic rights can the proletariat become aware of its class interests." - Rosa Luxemburg
Have 125 Population across all Settlements within {1_turn_timer}.
There is no progress if some are left behind.
Revolution advances, with a human heart.
Others may say that a true socialist movement must abandon the trappings of the past, but our people know better. One's past identity moves them forward.

"For the first time in my life, I have to grab the monks by the throat. Me! The most religious man in the Kingdom! Because I've had enough! My subjects and the elite among my subjects must obey!" - King Sihanouk
It is the people's palace, though only the monarch lives in it.
A new world, where all are equal under the eye of the state!
"I consider it completely unimportant who in the party will vote, or how; but what is extraordinarily important is this – who will count the votes, and how." - Joseph Stalin
Record the right numbers, not the correct ones.
If all work for all, all will benefit.

An archaeological expedition uncovers what looks like a thousand-year-old temple to a formerly unknown religious movement. It seems to have been brutally suppressed many years ago, but maintained a flourishing underground for some time.

The prince is a slim, boyish-looking man with a gift for languages and a love of travel, able to be at home in even the most different of lands. He asks, in the politest terms possible, for Siam to extend its trade outwards, that its people might see the luxuries the world has to offer.
An army is, at its core, no better than its commanders.
"We hope that this education will teach that unity with Bangkok is a good thing. If they do good, they will receive good things." - Chulalongkorn
The blood of international friendships is trade.

What was once foreign can become familiar. Despite her "Lao" customs and ways, her long hair – so unlike the short, spiky cut favored by court women, and odd accent, the princess of the North brings charm, and the arts of her province. "If only," she muses, "we had sufficient space to showcase our arts..."
Even the most remote places can beautify the court.
"The Lord of Chiang Mai held his daughter, and said 'We must send you to Siam and lose one dear thing, rather than losing all.'" - Khun Chang Khun Phaen
The court is the heart and soul of the people.

Itsarasunthon is a fair artist – but better than that, he has an eye and an ear for the fit. In his circle are poets who bring the magic of Siamese folklore to bear upon the everyday rhythms of Thai life – composers who blend foreign patterns and instruments with Siamese melodies and craftsmen who bring a subtle artistry to life along the canals.
The beauty of the land lies amidst the spires of the palace.
"May the true religion never die." - Sunthorn Phu
The beauty of the land lies in its streets and canals.

Plaek Phibulsongkran – Phibul – is no prince, but a military commander with a new vision for the nation. "We should think of ourselves not as the royal Siamese," he proclaims," but the militant Thais, and build a nation where tanks and not just garuda extend our glory."
The army's strength lies in its administration.
"We must be as cultured as other nations, otherwise they will come to us as superiors." - Phibul
The army's strength lies in the hearts of its commanders.

Viceroy Pinklao leans forward, adopting an elder-brother air. "The march of progress is not done alone," he says. "We can learn from foreign ways, but still retain our Siamese hearts. We should start in our riverside districts, where the foreign meets the Siamese."
The city's elite guide the populace towards civilization.
"The four-legged jungle beasts that hear my music calm, and sleep blissfully. Music is the noblest art. " - Sunthorn Phu
The countryside flocks to the city, bringing a new flood of fresh faces...and ideas.

A new nation needs a new order. But Pridi advises rejecting the siren call of militant nationalism. The true voice of the people arises from democracy, he says and true peace comes with friends who love peace. "Can a nation be free, if its people are not?"
Through cultivating and learning foreign allies, Siam progresses.
"If each party honestly pursues the common benefit of the nation...even if each takes a different route to their objective, we will meet each other in the end." - Pridi
Through cultivating its brightest minds, Siam progresses.

Sakdiphonlasep knows well that with one hand the gods offer a mudra in prayer, and in the other, they hold a sword. Despite his avuncular face and soft words, it is clear he favors the sword. Enemies are near, and to defeat them will call for heroes.
The records of Siamese conquests enter the realm of myth.
"The king of the capital city governs with justice and forthrightness, providing citizens and soldiers alike with joy." - Khun Chang Khun Phaen

Maha Senanurak has a face like leather, with iron-gray hair brushed stiffly upwards. He promises to crush enemy warriors on the field of battle, if only he is permitted to leave the comfort of the palace for the sway of the howdah.
"I fled not. I mounted the elephant and rode him in front of my father. I engaged the enemy in elephant-duel, and he was beaten." - Ramkhamhaeng the Great
Siam enshrines its conquests upon its landscape.

The soul of a nation is founded not in the military victories on the battlefield, but the tales told of their exploits. Vajiravudh, Rama VI, is a master at stirring the people's hearts through prose and theater.
Siam takes what is good from the world, and makes it its own.
"A nation without its own traditional culture is not regarded by outsiders as a nation at all." - Vajiravudh
Pride in the nation drives Siamese hearts, hands, and minds.

Wichaichan, his face tanned with days marching in column, advises that to survive colonization requires craftiness: to learn the invader's ways, but stay true to one's own. He runs his finger across a long scar to underline what he means by learning.
An army is, at its core, no better than its commanders.
"I ask you only to put yourself in the position of the ant whose nest is about to be stamped on by an enemy...we can give him some nasty bites." - Vajiravudh
An army is, at its core, no better than its recruits.
"Revolution is a fire, it's true," Desmoulins says reassuringly, "but we must ensure that we remain warmed by it, and not to let it consume us. Let us temper our ardor with joy."
Revolutions cannot solely tear down; they must rebuild.
"I shall die in the belief that to make France free, republican and prosperous, a little ink would have sufficed – and only one guillotine." - Camille Desmoulins
A whisper on a spark can ignite a firestorm of freedom.
Georges Danton appears impeccably dressed in his coat and powdered wig, finery that contrasts with the scars across his face. Here is a man who cheers for struggle, but delights in comfort.
Scars are credentials for battle-tested leaders.
"Audacity, then again audacity, always audacity!" - Georges Danton
The future is not won through conservative policy.
Declaration of the Rights of Women

Word has gone around the capital about a new group of writers and thinkers in the capital, one that dares to address the lack of women amongst those pushing for social reform. Other Jacobins balk at her ideas of uniting democracy and monarchy, but her salons are always filled to capacity.
Declaration of the Rights of Women
Society is muted when half its voices are silenced.
"Women, wake up...recognize your rights. The torch of truth has dispersed all the clouds of folly." - Olympe de Gouges
Both sides have a duty to demolish the wall between the sexes.

The rumors about Billaud Va Renne, the "righteous patriot", precede his arrival. Gossip swirls that his ardor verges on bloodlust, but his words are measured. "There are those," he announces, "in foreign lands still laboring under the yoke of oppression." His meaning is clear.
Freedom for all breeds progress for everyone.
"However painful an amputation may be, when a member is gangrened it must be sacrificed." - Jacques Nicolas Billaud-Varenne
Workers should be paid not chained.
Brissot heads a group uncharitably called "the War Party," who see in the enemies of France enemies of liberty itself. Their aims could not be more clear.
True heroism comes from knowing when to eschew bloodshed.
"The disorganisers are those who want to level everything...because they have none of these things." - Jacques Pierre Brissot
The key to peace lies in the size of one's army.

Marat has a mouse's face, with wide, expressive eyes. His newspaper is "the Friend of the People," though its pages list more enemies than friends. "If we had places where this message could be better heard..." he begins.
"Man has the right to deal with his oppressors by devouring their palpitating hearts." - Jean-Paul Marat
Novels tantalize with fiction. The public press does likewise with fact.
Etta Palm is a spy. This much is true, though for whom and against whom the accounts differ. Though she makes friends easily, the list of grievances against her continues to rise.
Diplomacy hides intentions behind a smile.
"Justice must be the first virtue of free men, and justice demands that the laws be the same for all beings, like the air and the sun." - Etta Palm d'Aelders
Become Suzerain of an Independent Power.
Information can be a tool, a currency, or a weapon. Sometimes all three.
Louis Antoine de Saint-Just is a beautiful young man, a countenance that jars with his sobriquet. "To those who oppose us," he counsels, softly, "we cannot show mercy."
Revolution is a journey. Without effort, empires go nowhere.
"When a people, having become free, establish wise laws, their revolution is complete." - Louis Antoine de Saint-Just
Victory only comes after adversity. Triumph only after a trial.

Abolition, tolerance, suffrage – and also violence, purges, and the Terror. These are the words that swirl around Maximillien Robespierre. "A sacrifice done for liberty is a gift." His eyes show that he means this for himself as well as others.
The blood of armies is used to ink constitutions.
"Citizens, did you want a revolution without a revolution?" - Maximilien Robespierre
Achieve a Celebration with Reign of Terror Active.
An oppressed nation crawls along. A revolutionary spirit leaps ahead.

Dressed in a formal coat and wig, Paul Barras stands proudly at attention. "A directory," he announces, without preamble, "a committe of rule with absolute authority. This is the path forward for France, and against its enemies."
People who cannot rule themselves will fight for themselves.

"People do not judge in the same way as courts of law; they do not hand down sentences, they throw thunderbolts; they do not condemn kings, they drop them back into the void; and this justice is worth just as much as that of the courts.” - Maximilien Robespierre
The only value of injustice is how it inspires revolution.
The recent hurricane washes out the beach, revealing an old shipwreck. Excavating the site will destroy the aging wood, but may yield artifacts.
Rebury the ship to preserve the aging wood.

An explosion of new writing styles pushes the boundaries of storytelling in Meiji Japan, and a popular writer pens an article calling to revolutionize the novel. The ideal work, he asserts, is one that treats realism as a form of art.
Announce a search for the perfect novel.

As Meiji industry strengthens, so too do the arts. Poets and authors lean into the natural world and its connection to the deep past, seeking solace in nature beyond the city. But what of the din of the zaibatsu, what of style rooted firmly in realism and observation?

Many novels are being written in an approachable colloquial style that help the reader feel more connected to the language on the page. This shift in style is causing controversy among scholars, who have strong feelings about what literature should be.
The widely-read vernacular novel sparks experimental trends.
Formal, scholarly standards reflect and strengthen social order.

The quality of miniature paintings reaches new heights in the Mughal world, and a courtier proposes immortalizing the moral tales of a talkative parrot. Another protests that a more fitting subject would be the epic of an ancient hero.
Commission the tales of the Tutinama.

The expansion of Mughal culture opens the doors to outside influence, and painters shift toward single-point perspective work. The art community excitedly leverages this new technique, producing a wide variety of paintings across many genres – portraits, historical scenes, court celebrations. The public is particularly fixated on a painting of a fight between a spider and a snake.
Art should bring joy, no matter the subject matter.

The Mughal Empire resounds with the melodies of its people. Voices and instruments combine in rāgas of all forms – the imaginative khyal, the syllabic tarana, the ancient dhrupad – while new creations, such as the sitar, add nuance to existing ensembles.
The people's innovation is here laid plain.
Such music spreads the language of the soul across the world.

The dawn of modernity breaks over America, and politicians put pen to paper to define the way forward. While articles on government and the building blocks of state proliferate, so too do poets paint the beauty and nuance of new beginnings in verse.
Publish "Poems on Various Subjects, Religious and Moral."

The rise of American industry has changed its very imagination. As the machines of production roar onward, much literature begins to reflect a longing for the simple past, and the rawness of emotion and nature. Other authors take the opportunity to criticize society's present through realistic snapshots.
In times of progress, one must reflect on what is constant.
Critique in the present may hold off future ills.
As America's borders expand, many flock to new frontiers to start afresh. Photographers attempt to capture the wilderness on glass plates, and writers imagine the freedom and romance of open country.
Fund a competition for adventure stories.

A collective of prominent Prussians form a new academy of the arts, and begin hosting meetings in the ballroom of an old palace. Before long, they seek a formal nominee for their program director who can represent what they consider to be the core artistic disciplines.

The rapid advancement of military industry motivates many Prussian composers to draw inspiration from the smoke of cannon fire and sonorous steam engines, capturing the grandeur of war through music. Other new compositions respond with softer sounds inspired by forests and mountains.
Now is the time for marching songs!
Music should soothe the battle-hardened heart.

War and its constant march of innovation see a vivid reply in the Prussian literary world. Popular novels sprawl in tribute to the glory of war, while others conserve poetry as a corner for quiet reflection on the many fallen.
The novels attest to great wartime achievements.
The poems remind us of our honor.
A group of gold miners announce they no longer wish to pay taxes. They declare secession from America and raise a new flag over their settlement – that of the Great Republic of Rough and Ready.

As pressure from the government mounts, the miners run low on food and supplies. With no chance of standing against America’s might, they reluctantly acquiesce to the demands of the nation and disband the Republic of Rough and Ready.
For the Love of the Party
Leave the men to their fun.
On the Fourth of July, Rough and Ready citizens are denied beer in a nearby town because they are "foreigners."[N]They immediately disband their young nation and join the festivities.

As Siam becomes a force to be reckoned with, many people see an endorsement of their divine beliefs and call for unity to strengthen their position on the world stage. However, the rural folk hold dear their diverse traditions, and are reluctant to let them go.
Customs and practices thrive on variety.

Residents of the new bang discover a strange stele in an elephant paddock. The inscription relates the history of an ancient ruler and his kingdom, and some scholars eagerly claim these are the roots of Siam – if indeed such a thing can be described by a single narrative.
History's arc is a single line.
There are many ways to make sense of the past.

The industrialization of Siam means an acceleration in the comings and goings of new ideas. Innovation is a constant inspiration to entertainment, from the epic ballads of court poets to new painterly visions of the world beyond its borders.
Fund a painting in the newest style.

Even in what folk call enlightened times, many people still turn to the divine for answers. Even though history has proven that faith can be inventive, misinterpreted, even manipulated, the human fascination with the unknowable still persists.
The mysteries of the divine are an eternal pursuit.
It is time to deal only with what can be proven.
A Norman tapestry has been discovered in the archives of the museum, its skilled needlework telling a tale of great conquest.
Display the work at the museum.
Study it further for additional value.

The construction of a new tenement leads to a spectacular find: an ancient marketplace. Yet archaeologists find fewer coins and artifacts than they anticipated, speculating that the ancient people must have faced a poor economy.
Fund an exhibit on ancient civilization.
Commission research into the economics of the past.

The construction of a new tenement leads to a spectacular find: an ancient marketplace. Archaeologists unearth a plentitude of old coins, and conclude that these people must have lived in the midst of an economic boom.
Open the dig site to tourists.
Study the economics of the past.

The Mexican people clamor for new directions and find inspiration in literature. Many novels emerge exploring today's politics through the past's fantasies, seeking political unity through narrative. But a new wave of writers prefers to channel reality through their words and confront the world head-on, raw and unhindered by metaphors.
Fiction offers creative perspectives on the real world.
The only way to solve problems is to face them directly.

Mexican citizens gather in the zócalo to debate the plaza’s central decoration. According to an ancient myth, a divine message foretold the founding of a city at the place where an eagle consumed a serpent. The people marvel at how far they have come, and make plans for a statue honoring this mythic past.
Even the oldest myths hold hidden truths.
Now the past will always be remembered.
The declaration of the Plan of Iguala opens a new chapter in Mexico’s story. Citizens are excited about its three guarantees: religion, independence, and unity.

As France flourishes on the world stage, so too does its population of writers, artists, and creative visionaries. Readers appreciate the ways in which literary realism captures their world on the page, prompting the audience to confront society's problems and think through solutions. Yet symbolism grows increasingly popular, offering distance from the quotidian to explore life's truths on a broader level.
Realism is the clearest lens on the world.

A tight-knit coalition of fussy neighbors will never be happy with any change. When the narrow city roads are widened, they long for the historical cobbles, and when contemporary architecture is erected, they complain of eyesores ruining the character of the area.
Progress will come for them all in the end.
Preservation is a worthy use of their time.

The establishment of the Code civil des Français has the French populace talking. No longer behind a veil, the law is now accessible in the vernacular of all, and this new transparency will surely create a change in how people understand empire.

Urban populations enjoy the literary scene developed by Russian authors. Many appreciate solitary explorations of humanity, war, and spirituality through novels, while the more visually inclined are drawn instead to more concentrated evenings at the theater, followed by spirited discussions over late-night feasts.
Books make philosophers of us all.
The stage draws great thinkers together.

In one another, the farming collective of the obschina has found a safety net against the hazards of life. The Cossacks don't always understand, however, wondering why anyone would ever relinquish the freedom of the steppe.
As Russian power unifies, aristocrats grow anxious, fearing a loss of authority in their own territories. They will cling to power, even until it fractures.
Provincial authority delegates power to those most familiar with it.
Centralized power reforms the empire in preparation for a new future.
Thanks to their rigorous training, the warriors of Buganda are getting faster in their attacks, completing raids in less time than ever. Their appetite to conquer only grows.
As the waves of Kabaka's Lake whisper gently behind him, the mwami instructs his army on the nature of war.
War is best won by defense.
A strong offense is the way.

The interconnectedness of the people is tied to the land, its many paths, and the gifts it bears to those who tend it well. But some worry that the rise of industry – the belching factories, the screaming trains, the thundering weapons – will fracture their communities.

An enemy officer surveys the white landscape through frosty binoculars. The tundra is empty. No foes in sight. His unit is safe, for now.[N][N]A small movement draws his attention. And as the lenses swing back to a hillock, his blood runs cold.[N][N]Figures are silently rising from the snow. Perfectly camouflaged against the terrain, the Russian soldiers raise their weapons, take aim, and fire.

The economy is booming, and traders flock to the stock market to invest their savings – and the savings of others. They debate the future of share prices as they crunch numbers, arguing whether to risk further speculation or play it safe and let the market run its course.

The stock market continues to rise, and the traders' speculative gambles pay off with a small bonus to everyone’s investment. Cheering the brokers' preternatural instincts, the public boosts their investments.

Stockbrokers gaze up at the numbers in stunned dismay. Their speculation gamble has become a disaster. Every newspaper declares “Panic as Stocks Crash!” as citizens who rush to withdraw their savings find there is no longer any to be had.

The stock market bustles with unhappy faces as traders murmur to one another about the drop in prices. It is not the end of the world, they reassure themselves, but well-intentioned constraints on speculation have bitten back, and it will take time to recoup both their losses and the trust of the public.

Commodities fly off shelves as the citizens pour their hard-earned money back into the thriving economy. Stockbrokers congratulate one another on the caution they showed in scaling back speculation, which surely helped stabilize prices.

A politician finishes off the delicious petals of sliced fish served to him by his innkeeper. He insists on knowing the source of his delight, and is shocked to find that it is the illegal pufferfish.
Fine all those who serve it.

The breaking of ground for a new city park unearths ancient ruins below the earth. Archaeologists are called in at once to translate an ancient tablet found at the dig site. Its harsh language curses a thief for stealing clothes from a bathhouse.
This tablet will look wonderful in a museum.
Schoolchildren will delight in translating this tablet in Latin class.

As the city's fortifications are completed, builders discover an ancient cemetery. An archaeologist extracts a worn lead tablet, cursing an unfaithful man in shocking language. The museum wishes to display the object, but a scholar of ancient Greek declares it a prime specimen of vernacular language.
This tablet belongs in a museum.
The poorest of society deserve support.
New radio setups are deployed to key military communications officers, but not everyone finds the manual accessible.
Tap out messages in Morse code.
A buzz of static roars through the command tent at the war's frontlines. After a moment, a voice rings out, confirming that the big guns are ready for action.
As guns roar at the front line, a soft tapping emerges from a radio speaker in the command tent. Once decoded, the message says it's time to bring in the cavalry.

Archaeologists digging up the site of an ancient academy find a vault buried beneath the courtyard. They gather round and slowly open the lid to find a collection of old coins and gems. Their ancestors must have been rich indeed!

A tourist walking the grounds of an ancient academy spots a strange door peeking out of the earth. Local archaeologists open the vault to find personal valuables and cultural treasures from an ancient era. They are thrilled at such an intimate window into the past.

Students at an elementary school prepare to bury a time capsule. As they dig, a shovel hits against a buried vault. There is already a time capsule here![N][N]Through a hole in the ceiling, they spot scrolls and manuscripts – a priceless library of ancient knowledge.
Construction workers erecting a new building uncover a valuable heirloom. Archaeologists surmise they must have been buried during wartime, but no one knows what became of their previous owners.
The pork and beef industries run strong in your empire – too strong. Their gluttony is unmatched, and rumors abound that their masters have secret tails.
Reports come in from a small town on the fringes of the empire – for a year, every child is born with a pig's snout. "Porker's revenge," it is being called.
"Milk stains on the rug. Ghostly barking in the night," wails the young aristocrat. "Why, oh why did we venerate the pig? Will someone save me from this torment?"

A pair of ancient golden horns are stolen under cover of night. When the thief is eventually arrested, the people learn their priceless relics have been melted down by an overzealous goldsmith, and grieve their loss.
Honor the loss in a memorial exhibit.

An artist commemorates the unearthing of the first of two golden horns, painting a young woman pulling the root-shrouded treasure from the earth. Nature reveals the secrets of the past only to the pure of heart, the artist says in his statement. Though the horns are lost forever, more treasures may await the virtuous.

"Two glimpses from ancient days glimmer in the new era," the poet writes. His words are a literary stand-in for the pair of golden horns lost to theft, celebrating the eternal presence of those marvels that spoke across the ages.

As the train pulls into the station, a novelist puts a final flourish on his signature. He tucks the letter into the envelope and sighs – so many letters penned to his rival the playwright, yet never any response. How long will it take, he wonders?
The mail is a site for free expression.

A famous playwright is said to have a portrait of his rival hanging above his fireplace, the better to inspire his great works. In the fireplace itself, a stack of the rival's unopened letters merrily burn.
A passionate rivalry is healthy for the arts.

Lively debates are in fashion about the depiction of nature in the arts. Some say nature is an authentic, mystical representation of the long-standing past, the land itself telling its own story. Others see the natural world as a key site of rational study.

A literary salon erupts into an argument over the future of literature. One reader rises to her feet, shaking her fist about the importance of symbolism and abstraction. Sharp words fly across the room from those who believe in the challenge of intensely realistic material instead.

Urban life draws more and more citizens into its orbit. Cities provide easy access to goods and products from around the world, as well as many jobs. But prices are also on the rise, and petitions grow for better working conditions.
Busy workers do not have time to protest.
A novelist publishes a book stating that nature is cold and dispassionate. Readers find this approach disturbing, and look with suspicion at their neighborhood parks.
It is only right to view nature pragmatically.
It is time to revive Romanticism.

On a busy commercial street, amid the discordant jangle of music, stands a shrine to Brahma, the lord of creation. Even as busy foot traffic comes and goes through the markets, dancers turn slowly in observance.
All business must pause to observe him.
He watches over the market's creativity.
In the heart are all gods,[n]In it the vital breaths also,[n]In the heart is life and light,[n]And the threefold thread of the world. - The Brahma Upanishad
A pilot is swiftly spat from a plane and onto the runway. Though he is stunned, cheers greet his rise to his feet: the inventor's cockpit catapult design is finally a success!

As the bomber spirals toward the earth, the crew in the cockpit makes one last prayer before activating the new seat catapult designed to safely eject them. They launch swiftly into the air, parachutes fluttering in the wind as they drift, alive and well, to a safe landing.

Ducking into a bombed-out home, soldiers come face to face with a huddle of airmen hiding from enemy gunfire since they ejected from their doomed bomber. The soldiers swiftly support the airmen to a safe place.

As soldiers prepare the next offensive, several figures emerge from a nearby copse. The bomber crew, having ejected successfully during their crash, have finally made their way home from behind enemy lines, exhausted but alive.

In light of the recent shipwreck, several volunteers have formed the Life-Saving Service to rescue future victims of the seas. Sailors are relieved to have support on land if anything happens, and many already celebrate the surfmen as heroes.

The Life-Saving Service springs into action, saving as many sailors as they can from the sinking vessel even though some of their own lives are lost. To honor their fallen comrades, the surfmen adopt a new motto: "You have to go out, but you don't have to come back."
All over the neighborhood, every household seems to have its own beloved black cat to feed. A local veterinarian, however, insists it's all the same cat, scamming for food.
Cats should live their best lives.
While taking a walk along the capital’s river, a girl finds the abandoned skin of a massive snake. The creature’s whereabouts are unknown.
Citizens should travel in groups for safety.
The serpent has probably moved on.

Since the discovery of the snakeskin on the riverbank, many citizens hunt for the creature. As the doors to the new tenement open, its new inhabitants excitedly enter – and swiftly exit. A large snake has been found in the basement!
Whoever released this rare snake must be punished.
This snake looks far smaller than the skin from the riverbank...

A massive snake has become something of a local celebrity in town. Residents report glimpses of the beast they call "Fangs" with equal parts fear and fervor, but for some reason, tourists seem hesitant to get excited.
Add Fangs to the city’s flag.

The lights dim as the new opera begins. Suddenly, a scream – and a massive snake slithers onto the stage![N][N]Chaos erupts as citizens scramble for the exit. Ushers plead for safe evacuation as several brave guests wade against the tide in a bid to capture the interloper.
The building must be evacuated at once.

The opera house is evacuated with the sound of screams after an unexpected guest star made its way onto the stage: the local giant snake, who eludes the hunters once again. Certainly it has been an unforgettable night at the opera.
Find the snake at all costs.

Several citizens emerge from the opera house, each clinging to part of a massive snake. They stagger under its weight as it hangs limply and observes the crowds, accepting that its time on the lam is over. The serpent will enjoy the rest of its life at a local sanctuary.

A city state leader expresses discomfort with the balance of power in her alliance with Prussia. She requests a renegotiation of the deal to bolster her authority. Several diplomats advise that she may be pacified with a shallower expression of good will.

Whalers drag up their most recent catch, only to find they have captured two creatures at once. Attached to the whale is a huge tentacled beast. The captain cries out that the legendary kraken is real!
It must be a giant squid.

Following the stock market crash, frantic traders look for ways of mitigating damage. Some financial experts recommend cutting interest rates, but other number-crunchers, equally credentialed, say that further meddling can only make things worse.
Cutting interest rates makes the stock market shiver, yielding a reluctant little uptick. Any victory, no matter how small, seems like progress to the traders.

Surprising everyone, the "do nothing" approach allows time to correct the stock market's prospects by a significant margin. Citizens still feel financially insecure, but the start of a long recovery process for the economy comes as a relief nonetheless.
Establish a government program to reduce unemployment.

As the New Deal goes into effect, citizens rejoice to find themselves back at work. Although they still fear the volatility of the stock market, they begin to rebuild their trust in the economic system.

The significant profits gleaned from the export of silk have caught the appetite of producers and merchants alike. There are calls to expand the industry, even while advisors fear the business is too delicate to form a spine for the Prussian market.

Entranced by the creative potential of radio, a theater company creates a unique broadcast: mysterious lights in the sky, troops deployed, and citizens under siege. It is a thrilling new kind of story, but unfortunately, many believe it's really happening...
This is why media literacy matters.
The truth is stranger than fiction.

Among the gifts from the new suzerainty is an antique pendant watch, featuring an ivory cameo surrounded by red gems. It is exquisite, but when questioned about its origins, the envoys can only shrug.
See what price the watch will fetch.
A soldier breaks open a glass case, lifting an antique watch from inside. Red jewels form an entrancing halo around an ivory cameo, and the awestruck soldier wonders where such a beauty originated.
See if someone will pay for it.

At a private auction of antique timepieces, a hush falls over the crowd as particularly eye-catching item is unveiled: A pendant watch with red gemstone inlay and an ivory cameo. Then begin the murmurings: lovely piece, but its provenance is unknown.
More credible lots are on offer.

Many claim to be the true and rightful owner of a mysterious antique pendant watch with glittering red gems. One of the claimants submits some compelling evidence: could a certain etching in the metal in fact be a maker's mark?
Give the watch to the claimant.

Museum-goers thrill at a new acquisition: a distinctive antique pendant watch with an ivory cameo, displayed in a place of honor for all to see. Outside on the steps, a clamor grows as protesters gather to demand the artifact's return to its rightful owners.
Scientists discover that the recently rediscovered pendant watch is a counterfeit. Though convincing to the naked eye, the watch appears to keep time a little too well for its vintage.
There is much to be learned from a good forgery.
Legal trouble is brewing around the antique pendant watch. A coalition of antiquities dealers has come forward to claim it was purchased illegally, and demand it be returned.
The antique pendant watch has gone missing, its thieves unknown. Many decry the transgression, but who is to say the watch was acquired by legitimate means in the first place?
The theft will not soon be forgotten.

Every year, hordes of vacationers flock to the coast to spend their leisure time on the coast, nurturing the booming tourist economy there. But local workers are growing fatigued, many themselves unable to afford the luxuries they work to provide to visitors.
Improve the locals' quality of life.
With the tourism industry restrained, locals are able to enjoy their own home town again. Still, the squeeze of lost profits darkens the shoreline just as surely as a storm cloud in summer.

The land is transformed by pleasures and attractions, and coffers overflow as the streets are flooded with tourists. But the locals no longer recognize the place they grew up, living in a funhouse theme park of their own culture.

On the new train station's platform, a young woman weaves among plumes of steam and chattering crowds. Clutching a suitcase tight, she looks around one last time, before climbing up into the train that will take her into the future.

An odd but somehow familiar portrait is unearthed, done in a once-fashionable mosaic style, depicting a leader who smiles with a distinctive uncanny wince. The art world is fascinated by this exceptional piece.
Ensure the portrait has a place of honor in a museum.
See that the portrait is conveniently "lost."

Recent consolidation means fresh enthusiasm for Augustus' mandates to organize the city. Architects compete to have their plans adopted and artists clamor to be part of a new wave of design – but many people quietly hope for a more practical civic life.
Culture should be on all doorsteps.
Open-air spaces will boost urban life.
The old quarter should be restored.

From a shop front, the aroma of cooked meats and spices washes over the throngs in the city streets. A few enterprising chefs recall the old traditions of their ancestors, opening cook-shops on busy corners. Lately, the people's attention has been captivated by one particular dish.
If Augustus is pleased with coarse bread and dates, then so will his people be.

Flurries of pamphlets circulate: is this new system true democracy? Some argue that it is a break from the long-held traditions of their ancestors – others point out that those traditions had inconsistencies as well. The debate rages over what a democracy should be.
Democracy is about everyone having an equal voice.
Democracy is about the votes of productive citizens.

Democracy is an ever-evolving process, the most persuasive citizens argue. They say a true democracy is one where every person receives one vote. But detractors are unconvinced, and continue to circulate their own pamphlets.

Persuasive citizens insist that only civic participation can determine the direction of the government. A thriving democracy must be run by those with the greatest stake in preserving it, they say. Detractors remain unconvinced, however, and continue to circulate their own literature.

Inventors are finding more and more novel uses for natural rubber, and stockpiles have begun appearing all over {1_capital}. Its distinct odor has become an omnipresent fume, spoiling food, fabrics, and the very flavor of the air. On hot days, formless, foul-smelling shapes haunt the citizens' dreams.
They will stop noticing the smell in time.
+3 Food and +3 Happiness on Grocers, but -3 Production on Factories in all Settlements.
-3 Food and -3 Happiness on Grocers, but +3 Production on Factories in all Settlements.

Weary crewmembers stumble down the gangway of a merchant vessel that has recently docked in the port. Many scratch at their rashes or are covered in sores, but the manifest lists a hundred more who were not so lucky. The captain claims a supply of fresh fruit would prevent such significant crew losses in the future.
I Haste My Bread to Earn

A booming coal operation shudders to a halt. For the first time since the mines opened, the pickaxe's steady clink stops sounding in the deep tunnels, and songs of protest rise up instead, as the miners form a picket line to agitate for better wages and safer working conditions.
Scab workers will finish the job.
Although the people generally understand the need to tighten belts when there's a war on, sugar rations are the quickest to run out. Tea with no sugar? That is where many draw the line.
Now that there's enough sugar for tea, the citizens find life that little bit sweeter.

Among their latest haul, pearl divers have found something that sets the community afire: a massive blue pearl, the rarest of all. There is guaranteed wealth associated with the treasure, but its like has never been seen, may never be seen again. The pearl's finder tosses and turns through sleepless nights.
Display the treasure in a museum.
Sell it and pay the workers a windfall.

Plenty of folk thought it was loony to build an opera house in a coal town, of all places. But now, tourists flock from all over to see the dazzling shows and events. It's enough to inspire the local coal workers to imagine the world beyond their toil.

The riverside huts burn in the silent dark. Local say this place, Phrakhanong, is haunted by a woman whose husband was conscripted for the military. Left to die alone, she swears revenge against any army that passes through.
Again, Phrakhanong burns. Again, locals whisper of ghosts.

The time has come to deal with this spirit, if it is indeed a spirit. A monk close to the palace claims that he can bring it peace by convincing it to renounce its hatred, while the locals say a medium can catch the ghost in a jar.
The monk sits over the grave of Nak, and delivers the sermon. Afterwards, he offers a forehead bone, promising it will bring great power.
The medium returns with a clay jar covered in sutras. The ghost is sealed inside, he claims.
The people are haunted by something more than a ghost: the lamentations of war, and the cries that have gone unheard. A shrine will be built to Nak, to tell her story.

As the new alliance takes shape, a foreign diplomat inquires about our most recent war – were we the victim or aggressor? A counsellor advises that although the truth is valuable, sometimes one must write their own history.
Wealth flows through the land like a river, offering up priceless nourishment: economic security.
Strength is best measured by the skill of its use. Wisdom sharpens power's blade.
Duty to one another is duty to the self. Diplomacy grows more powerful with practice.
Over the horizon, there is always another horizon. Reach grows like the dawn.
The people look at one another and ask: who are we? Their cultural heritage deepens.
Progress marches on, driven by discovery. The people's thirst to know the workings of the world cannot be quenched.

Harried parents with screaming children clinging to their legs beseech Confucius: everyone deserves the gift of a sharp mind, not only the elite and enlightened. A reasonable argument, but resources are scarce.
The capital schools' standards must be maintained.

The brush hesitates over the page, a drop of ink trembling at its tip, and the writer frowns. It is oftentimes difficult to earn a living from a passion, and hard to know what will sell these days: a lyrical piece on the meaning of the self, or a treatise on being part of a greater picture?
It is a time for writings on individuality.
Themes of collectivism are most relevant now.
The sharp tang of citrus mingles with the salt scent of the sea. It smells of sweet relief to the sailors, who no longer fear scurvy on their long journeys.
The Prussian military is renowned as the most efficient killing machine of its time. In the march of the Hussars, in the hooves of their horses, one hears the beat of death's drum.
Hold a parade to honor their terrible glory.
Incorporate their ways into the social fabric.
Invaders storm the Red Fort, the people's bastion, desecrating and despoiling everything in their path.
The katikkiro, a royal son just into manhood, needs direction on his next training exercises. He wishes to develop the skills the empire most needs.
Speak to foreign nobles as an equal.
The son-in-law of one of the greatest chiefs shows promise – a steely resolve in the face of terror, a deft step in the sparring ring.
The Institute for Abbasid History is in a sorry state. Run-down and underfunded, it struggles to get its message commemorating Abbasid legacy to the public.
Construction of new infrastructure has hit a snag, as a prominent group of local activists seek to protect lands they say still retain mana from the people's Hawaiian days.
Pay respect to the ancestors first.
As ground is broken in the new urban zone, a glint of metal catches the sunlight. With a hush of awe, workers draw a chevaler's sword from beneath the earth.
Don Pedro strolls about the ruined plaza in the garb of ancient Spanish royalty, his head held high.
He is the guardian of Spanish history.
In the capital, the old trading houses of the Chola years still stand the test of time.
They are eyesores on the contemporary skyline.

A noble grandmother takes her youngest grandchild into her lap, describing how in Majapahit times, her lineage descended from the gods themselves on Mount Meru. Her daughter listens cautiously at the hearth, thinking about how the nobles are regarded these days.
They are only an emblem of a bygone age.
The Songhai warriors once drummed the land with the beating of hooves, now silent.
The cavalry still wears their emblems.
In the remote, rural camp, horsemen still play old Mongol games: horse-racing, competitive mounted archery, and the like.
Siam is the name of a kingdom. But Siam has become a nation – a nation of the Thai people. Competing groups vie to be the heart of the Thais.
The military is our shield and sword.
In our scholars we will advance.

The distant settlements are like the fingertips of the nation's body. Their loss is not a grievous wound, but is a violation of sovereignty. The army masses to take them back, and the people mass behind them.
In the chaos of the canals is beauty: a clash of color, a riot of sound, a symphony of smells. The heartbroken poet sits by the bank and records it all.

The foreign armies come with administrators, schoolteachers, missionaries. New education centers are set up to transform citizens of one land into models of another. From the outskirts of the city, new partisans arise – domination can be lived with, but this is dissolution.
The nobles in the capital believe Trung Trac to be a skilled politician. The workers in the fields know her to be a goddess. As the infantry marches, they sing her praises.

On the production line, a worker notices their colleagues in a uniform row, completing task after task in much the same way. Automation promises to make life easier, but also to change the relationship to work.
Scientists say their work environment plays a key role in inspiring their innovation. A collective of researchers petitions for a new laboratory near nature, which they say will encourage them.
Build more laboratories near scenic views.
Nestled near lush vegetation and the humming of birds, the new laboratory quickly becomes a popular research site for motivated scientists.
A pretty view will only distract from progress.
How better to illustrate the power of China than through perfect brushstrokes? A local artist is commissioned to do a great historical work for the palace.
Commission work of a historic battle.
As the empire's military presence begins to dwindle, diplomats speak in hushed whispers of new plans to bolster imperial power abroad. Tension in the air, one picks up a brush and begins to write.
Propose new trade relations to bolster the economy.
Prepare an order to expand the military.

The Cohong serve as front-line representatives for barter and trade with the outside world, but it is quite a lot of responsibility for one small liaison group. As they wait at the port for the arrival of traders, the Cohong quietly discuss what kind of support might make their work easier.

An independent ambassador presented the emperor with a gift. Upon opening it, they realized it was a piece of sophisticated technology unlike anything they've seen before. Curiously, the emperor weighed his options.
Take the device apart, learn how it works.
Crowds murmur in shock as a citizen refuses to bow to {1_leader} upon meeting. In old times, such disrespect would not stand, but perhaps obeisance is evolving these days.
They did not know the custom.
The gusa guard their home turf with the ferocity only a renowned cavalry can display. It would be a mistake for enemy forces to present themselves now.
A child walks with his mother along the Great Wall, trailing a hand over the jagged stone and its texture of the past. His little fingers come away blackened by soot from the nearby factory.
The Great Wall withstands the march of time.
The nearby factory reminds us of progress.

Society seems to have overcome its resistance to rapidly expanding railway travel, embracing new opportunities for trade and employment. But there is always room to improve transit, especially now that acceptance of railroads as a public good is growing.
Add more trains on existing routes.

The Mountain Resort is dotted with lakes and gardens, with pagodas made of intricate glazed tiles. Lotus flowers ripple in the breeze across a beautiful pond. {1_leader} takes in the scenery, and the knowledge such serenity has no price.
Charge a fee to access the gardens.

Archaeologists have discovered a site from the {1_archaeology_age} age. After conducting a careful excavation, they unearth {2_archaeology_source_civ: gender *:an?an; other?a;} {2_archaeology_source_civ_adj} [b]{3_archaeology_reward}[/b].

Archaeologists uncover remnants of {1_archaeology_independent}. This village was short-lived, having been dispersed by the {2_archaeology_source_civ_adj} civilization during the {3_archaeology_age} age.
A well-preserved {1_archaeology_source_civ_adj} [b]{2_archaeology_reward}[/b] is all that is left of the dissolution of {3_archaeology_independent}.
The Ravages of War and Time

There is sometimes no surer sign of human civilization than a settlement ravaged by war. Whatever the conflict, the {1_archaeology_source_civ_adj} soldiers of the {2_archaeology_age} age were here, whether victors or not.
A well-preserved [b]{1_archaeology_reward}[/b] survives to tell the story of the {2_archaeology_source_civ_adj} people.
There are signs of ancient, immense ambition dating to the {1_archaeology_age} under these foundations: something meant to stand the test of time but went unfinished.
In place of that unrealized dream, a humble [b]{1_archaeology_reward}[/b] speaks of the {2_archaeology_source_civ_adj} people's legacy.

In the shadow of {1_archaeology_volcano}, explorers find the bones of {2_archaeology_source_civ: gender *:an?an; other?a;} {2_archaeology_source_civ_adj} neighborhood laid to waste by the great mountain during the {3_archaeology_age} age.
It could not destroy everything: a well-preserved {1_archaeology_source_civ_adj} [b]{2_archaeology_reward}[/b] lies among the archaeologists' findings.

Time is a raging river, but not even it can completely wash away the ancient inhabitants of this settlement. The {1_archaeology_age} age saw the {2_archaeology_river} swell, but what could be found in the depths of history?
A well-preserved {1_archaeology_source_civ_adj} [b]{2_archaeology_reward}[/b] floats to the surface of history.

Archaeologists uncover remnants of {1_archaeology_independent}. This village was short-lived, having been dispersed by the {2_archaeology_source_civ_adj} civilization during the {3_archaeology_age} age. But a well-preserved [b]{4_archaeology_reward}[/b] survives to tell its story.
The Ravages of War and Time

There is sometimes no surer sign of human civilization than a land soaked with blood, and this [b]{1_archaeology_reward}[/b] confirms explorers' suspicions. Whatever the conflict, the {2_archaeology_source_civ_adj} soldiers of the {3_archaeology_age} age were here, whether victors or not.

There are signs of ancient, immense ambition dating to the {1_archaeology_age} age, the foundations of something meant to stand the test of time but went unfinished. In place of that unrealized dream, a humble [b]{2_archaeology_reward}[/b] speaks of the {3_archaeology_source_civ_adj} people's legacy.

In the shadow of {1_archaeology_volcano}, explorers find the bones of {2_archaeology_source_civ: gender *:an?an; other?a;} {2_archaeology_source_civ_adj} neighborhood laid to waste by the great mountain during the {3_archaeology_age} age. But it could not destroy everything: a well-preserved [b]{4_archaeology_reward}[/b] lies among the archaeologists' findings.

Time is a raging river, but not even it can completely wash away the ancient inhabitants of this floodplain. Though the {1_archaeology_age} age saw the {2_archaeology_river} swell, a lone {3_archaeology_source_civ_adj} [b]{4_archaeology_reward}[/b] held fast, and now floats to the surface of history.

While taking the old {1_archaeology_overbuilt_building} down to its foundations, workers stumble upon indications of an even older {2_archaeology_building}. The foreman calls for construction on the {3_archaeology_new_building} to halt while the value of this finding is appraised.
As they prepare to remove a well-preserved {1_archaeology_source_civ_adj} [b]{2_archaeology_reward}[/b], the archaeologists wonder just how many layers deep the past goes.

Archaeologists believe they have found evidence of {1_archaeology_source_civ: gender *:an?an; other?a;} {1_archaeology_source_civ_adj} {2_archaeology_building} beneath the rubble of a ruined {3_archaeology_overbuilt_building}. As they prepare to excavate, they wonder just how many layers deep the past goes.

At the majestic {1_RESEARCH_NATURAL_WONDER}, archaeologists, paleontologists, geologists, and botanists survey the local environs. Soon, museum curators will shape their findings into a display to capture the imagination of the public.
Diligent in their research, archaeologists uncover a wealth of knowledge about {1_RESEARCH_CONTINENT}'s recent past — more than enough to stoke the curiosity of museum goers back home.
Diligent in their research, archaeologists uncover a wealth of knowledge about {1_RESEARCH_CONTINENT}'s distant past — more than enough to stoke the curiosity of museum goers back home.
The finely-dressed young man, hand resting in a casual but suggestive way on his gun belt, introduces himself one more time as Amelio.
This man has the makings of a leader.
Amelio Robles Ávila slips from his mount, a colonel's uniform in place of the young man's suit. As he approaches his troops, his stride betrays the weight of hard-won experience.
Have 10 Soldadera Units and an Army Commander with 3 Commendations.
He is already a fine soldier.
Vicente Guerrero stands at the window of his office, thoughts clouded by the reminiscences of battle. The people look to him now as his soldiers once did.
The steel latticework of Mexico's railroads unites the country in industry. Schools promise freedom from oppression through education. This is Vicente Guerrero's legacy.
Have 4 Cities with a Rail Station and a Schoolhouse.

A few carefully placed explosives bring down the bridge, a definite blow to the enemy's supply lines. From a cloud of dust emerges the demolitionist's outline: a man's jacket and trousers, a woman's long black hair gathered under a hat. Her name is Petra Herrera.
She shall inspire the women of Mexico.

A sea of skirts, bandoliers and rifles aimed high: the soldaderas pose for the camera's flash. Once cooks and nursemaids to the "real soldiers," these women of the revolution, Petra Herrera among them, have come into their own.
Celebrate her, then send her on.
Father Hidalgo calls his people to him with the ringing of a church bell, its piercing cry insisting on the freedom and dignity of all.
Astride a great horse, Father Hidalgo waves the flag of Guadalupe before his followers. They will only end their march when justice is done.
Have 3 Army Commanders with 2 or more Commendations.
It came as no small shock when the young, bare-faced man revealed that his name was Ángela – and that she would no longer hide her true self, nor bandage others' wounds.
The soldaderas will prove they're more than serving-maids.
Those same men who had looked up to her when she was Ángel now regard her as Lieutenant Ángela Jiménez. Among those men stand women, too.
Have 4 Cities with a Military Academy and a Schoolhouse.
