Some fighters carry guns, but Benito Juárez carries a briefcase. His battlefield: the Palacio Nacional. The Flag of Mexico waves high overhead, reminding him of the importance of his mission.
Neither the loss of loved ones nor serious illness will deter Benito Juárez from his goals. He would bring lasting reform to Mexico, or die trying.
Mexico's strength is its educational system.
José María Morelos y Pavon slips one foot into his horse's stirrup and mounts his horse. He has heard his mentor's call for justice and wishes to answer, trading his priest's collar for battle dress.
The people break out in cheer when they see José María Morelos returning from victory. But he is humble, and insists that he is only a servant of the nation.
Remind the world who Mexico is.
The hand of Antonio López de Santa Anna rises and falls, signaling the firing squad. As his opponents fall, the smoke from the muskets billows past his impeccable uniform.
Let this be a lesson to the others.

Santa Anna orders a military funeral for the leg he had lost in battle, insisting that Mexico should never forget his sacrifice. As cannons fire in tribute, those closest to the general feign their bereavement.
Disperse an Independent Power or Capture a Settlement.
Move on to more pressing matters.
Silver ingots glint in the sunlight as Pancho Villa and his gang unload precious crates from the stalled freight train. The money they get for the silver will ensure they live to fight another day.
Pancho Villa strolls the thriving market. Not everyone may agree with his methods, but he holds his head high knowing that wealth is shared among all Mexicans, not just the privileged few.
Emiliano Zapata rides through the fields trailed by a legion of farmhands. They leave behind their plows and take up arms, vowing to fight for land and liberty.
The Zapatistas return to their plows, this time knowing that they work them not for the greedy landlords, but for themselves and each other.
The griots sing of nobility, and of the love of family. But hoofbeats and rifle fire have their own poetry. Amina's heartbeat keeps pace with the pounding of hooves and the rattle of wheels.
The song of war resounds deep within Amina. Her peoples' courage provides the harmony.
Another caravan arrives, laden with goods from across the seas of sand and salt. Camels have been replaced with trucks and sails with steam-clouds, and Amina watches the luxury flow in.
New wealth pours out of the factories, products of industry that now power the world and enrich the lives of the people. Always, Amina sits atop the profits.
Ashoka holds tight to his sword. The gods rule with strength as well as charisma – the chakravarti, the monarch who turns the wheel of dharma, is also the devaraja, the god-king.
Ashoka's architects have constructed a marvel. Now all will know of his deeds – his strength. The devaraja is eternal.
The sword slips from Ashoka's grasp. One cannot be the chakravarti – the king through whom the wheel of dharma turns – while holding weapons of war.
Discovery powers Ashoka's empire. Knowledge and production guide the path forward, and the people follow to greatness.
Build a Laboratory and a Factory.
The reputation of Augustus spreads through his artisans, his craftspeople, his architects. The world looks to his realm for inspiration…and he always delivers.
The past lives on in Augustus' empire, delivering lessons of the past to generations to come.
The people say Augustus is the "First Citizen," but they avert their eyes as he passes. The clerks and priests in the empire form a vast hierarchy, but Caesar is above it all.
Earth and sea alone could never contain Augustus. Now the very skies will be his, too.
Build an Aerodrome and Train a Squadron Commander.
In Franklin's inner circle, it is not the poet or the philosopher, nor the general or the flatterer who advances, but the one with a sober, practical eye toward problems and their solutions.

Across Franklin's realm, scholars investigate the mysteries of the universe. Their laboratories resound with the clink of beakers, the click of computers, and the whir of as-yet-nameless machines that promise a brighter tomorrow.

Those in Franklin's circle who term his court a "court" and his palace a "palace" stand quickly corrected. This is an assembly, congregating in a meeting house. The power of oratory triumphs over the naked use of force. People must be convinced, not coerced.
Franklin's oratory has proven effective. Through his advice, his people, and those of his allies, find inspiration and joy in life.
Beyond her cities of stone and glass, Catherine looks to other empires for inspiration. Upon the bedrock of exchange, her people build a society for the ages.
Catherine's populace does not only draw inspiration from others – they themselves inspire the world.
Catherine reigns over a realm of palaces. Laden with amber and gold, they represent more than vanity – they are a testament that power lies within beauty.
In the marvels of the past, Catherine and her people find the beauty of humanity. Across their history is written the story of their great potential.
Charlemagne burns with ambition, and so too does his army. Their flame exists only to consume.
Charlemagne lights his empire by setting the world aflame.
Upon the spark of electricity, Charlemagne's empire shines both day and night, illuminating the glory of his people.
Charlemagne's scientists work tirelessly to uncover the next leap forward, bringing his empire ever closer to the stars.
Every person faces challenges in their quest to achieve true moral character. Those who follow Confucius seek lessons from one another as they journey together.
Around the world, Confucian thought spreads among the people. They rejoice at their accomplishments, and their potential.
Have at least 2 Settlements each on Homelands and Distant Lands.

New ideas emerge on the nature of society, and people question the old ways with fresh eyes. But Confucius insists that the lessons of the past must be remembered – the world has shifted, but humanity remains a constant.
The sages of old practiced moral virtues to make the world a better place. Now, nurtured by Confucius, their lessons carry forth to future generations.

The army's grand procession marches from Friedrich's capital with horns blaring and pennants waving, celebrated by the people's cheers. To them, this is the world's greatest stage, with its poetry of cannons, its symphony of battle cries.
The army completes its performance, and Friedrich delivers a standing ovation. The choreography of his masterpiece has played out to perfection. Now, for the encore…
Violin bows slash the air and trumpet notes fire. Their battlefield is not for soldiers, but for lords in powdered wigs and ladies in elaborate dresses. Hearts will be lost today, but no blood shed.
Knowledge spreads quickly through Friedrich's empire, a melody of spring that promises a new tomorrow.
Many in the world seek a better life, some under the guidance of others, some through their own strength. Tubman hears these calls and prepares her response.
True power lies in freedom, and Harriet Tubman is here to aid it.
The world is changing, and new technology heralds fresh dangers on the battlefield. Tubman looks to her defenses – what will it take to stay one step ahead?
As planes soar overhead, Tubman's people feel their confidence rise. They know she will take care of them, as she always has.
Build an Aerodrome and a Military Academy.

One imagines that the immortality of pharaohs is in their tombs, static places awaiting their rebirth. But Hatshepsut’s empire breathes the life of the world in each moment – if there is a luxury to be had, it is to be had at her court. If there is a deal to be made, one looks for Hatshepsut’s solar disk as a mark of assurance. But with each age comes change, and a challenge.
With each age, a challenge...yet Hatshepsut, gazing across her lands of luxury, sees only success.

Hatshepsut’s legacy is evident, her face carved in stone in monuments for thousands of years. But the sand and wind wear away her features – and just as time weathers stone, so might it wear away at her authority. This must not be.
Artifacts line Hatshepsut's halls, testaments to past and present. But it is she who controls the story of the future.

Himiko gazes out upon the nation. From the prosperity of her ancient cities, to the quest for divine favor, to the grime of the industrial present, her people have learned that success comes through collective effort.
The museum's corridors fill with visitors, eager to witness artifacts of days past. The achievements of their makers paved the way for the present, just as Himiko's people craft the future.

The matsuri whirls and flashes with color and sound. The taiko drums, the laughter of children and the crack of toy guns echo in the cool shadows of the cypress trees. Himiko's presence is felt, but the kami are the true rulers.
The din of the factories resounds around the clock. They consume materials, spit out commodities – their raw power fuels Himiko's domain. Amaterasu's domain.
The desert is wide and the seas are vast, but the law remains the law. Where Ibn Battuta travels, he carries it with him, shining light upon darkened hearts.
Ibn Battuta carries the law to all who seek it – and with it, hope for a unified world.

The world is wide and the seas are vast. But Ibn Battuta knows that each new way of living, each unfamiliar custom encountered, and each uncharted landscape has its stories to tell and its goods to trade – fresh illumination in a darkening world.
Ibn Battuta once travelled to see the world. Now he controls it.
In Isabella's gaze, the sea is not blue – it is gold. More than wind and water, its currents stir the commerce and power where her empire thrives.
Much as Isabella's shipping routes traverse the oceans, so her railroads spread out over the land. Her networks draw in wealth from every quarter.
Isabella's crown remains a symbol of her enduring might. As her empire continues to grow, so too do the challenges – and the opportunities.
The world exists beneath Isabella's crown. Her power is unstoppable, and her territory ever-growing.
Times change, yet the poet's eye of José Rizal looks to the sea to connect the world.
The sea unites Rizal's people, and through its waves, they live and breathe as one.
Build an Opera House in Distant Lands and Homelands.

Many peoples, many governments, many cultures – diverse, yet all sharing the same world. José Rizal sits between them, listening and conversing, deftly weaving their dialogues among those of his people.
The modern era brings modern challenges. But Rizal remains at its heart, guiding discourse to peaceful ends.

Revolution provokes reaction, and new orders purify corrupt old ways like fire. The future breaks upon the people like a wave, but the past refuses to be drowned. Amid all of this, the spirit of humanity itself endures. Ultimately, people exist for one another.
Through war and peace, Lafayette guides his people to a brighter world, one build on the lessons of the past.
Behind every ideology, behind each flag, is a human face. No one struggles alone. And together, the people work toward collective liberation.
Lafayette's influence unites not only his own people, but those far beyond his borders. His leadership is more than political – it represents the promise of freedom.

Priests speak of a divine order: though it is beyond our own, its reflection is cast down onto earthly society. Machiavelli's people forge their own path, driven by self-interest – in this way, they climb to power.
States rise, states fall. Behind the scenes, Machiavelli's fingers make them dance.
History is not guided by the divine. It moves on the whims and interests of people. Namely, those of Machiavelli.
Machiavelli's cities are awash with factory smoke – and profit, and influence, and authority.

Though the tides of humanity swell among its foothills, the mountainside remains unmoved. People change their names and take up tools of iron and steel, but stone is still stone, speaking with ancient knowledge beyond any human tongue.
Factories never sleep. They consume raw materials and spit out finished products… and profits. Thus Pachacuti keeps his coffers full, and his people satisfied.
Under the condor, surrounding the puma, Pachacuti's people live on and thrive. The empire holds strong, even as the earth shakes.
Once, the earth shook. Now even the sky quakes beneath Pachacuti's might.
Build an Aerodrome and Train a Squadron Commander.
There are many ways to resolve conflict, but Trung Trac knows that military power is often the most straightforward path.
The world bows to Trung Trac. Does it have a choice?
Trung Trac sits on the throne, but the true power of her empire lies in her people. Together, they have endured and prospered. Together, they still have much to achieve.
No longer bound to the earth, Trung Trac's people take to the skies, together as always.

Xerxes's scientists proclaim that the earth goes around the sun, and the moon around the earth. As it is in heaven, so is it here, the ministers say. None question that Xerxes, the Shah of Shahs, stands at the center of creation, and around him his subjects orbit.
Xerxes sits at the heart of his empire. It revolves around him, producing tales of victory and wealth at every turn.
The banners of Xerxes surround the world. Now it will be reshaped by war.
The fires of Xerxes spread in every land, carried by soldier and civilian alike.
Never Anything to Do in this Town
The capital's population grows, but cultural life stagnates, with bored citizens milling in the streets and starting fights in the tavern. Many are hungry for ways to enrich their days and nights.
Invest in a nightlife expansion initiative.
New developments in nightlife have enriched the capital's social fabric, and few spend as many nights at home alone as they once did.
Have an Opera House and a Museum in {1_capital}.

A politician boards their first ever train, marveling at this new technology from abroad. As they lean out the window to wave farewell to their spouse, the implications of this rapid innovation are front of mind.
There is no choice but to embrace progress.
Expansion will likely have hidden consequences.

Since new trade began to flow, the plain woman's dearest friend has become unrecognizable: a stranger in fashionable western frocks. This must be what is popular now, she thinks, smiling politely, and resolving never to change.
Fashion is the science of human expression.

Laborers eye a newly hired colleague with equal parts curiosity and suspicion. The skilled worker from abroad is here to bring their practices apace with the rest of the world, but their appearance and ways have never been seen before.
Learn from the new worker's culture.
A disheveled samurai strokes the mane of his kisouma, coaxing out a sympathetic neigh. What use is his blade with no monarchy to serve, nor family to protect? Perhaps it is time for a different oath.
The time of the samurai is at an end.
The caste should turn toward charitable works.
Railway systems and telegraph cables spring up almost overnight, covering the land in a spiderweb of rubber and copper coils built to connect and transmit.
The speed of information will surely increase.
The fabric of culture will certainly shift.
As the diplomat sinks into the restorative waters of the Dogo Onsen, their body feels at ease. A clearer mind makes it easier to decide between soldiers and citizens.
Soldiers who have more time to rest are better equipped for battle.
+5 Healing on Infantry in Friendly Territory.
The armies grow stronger now that they are permitted to prioritize rest and well-being.
Prioritizing the wellbeing of our citizens comes first.
When the people feel cared for, their continued growth is assured. Prioritizing their well-being has been a stabilizing force.
The explosion that brought the dreadnought to the sea floor was unexpected and deadly. But the Mikasa has been raised from the ocean floor and built anew, refusing to be sunk again.
Allocate more workers to the shipyard.

The exclusive zaibatsu quarter is constantly abuzz with traders rushing about, making deals and securing stocks. Many wonder what it must be like to belong to one of the wealthy families of the in-crowd.
The work is harder than it looks.
There's a shift in the air. The soldiers feel it, the diplomats feel it...but does Tubman? A good leader knows when to pivot, but to admit their first instinct was wrong takes humility.
Trust the voice of the people.
Tubman watches a group of sign-wielding protesters picketing for their rights – the more things change, the more things stay the same, she reflects as she joins the crowd and their cause.

A group of protesters have begun to agitate for more transparency from their government. "We have a right to be informed on all decisions," the protest leader insists. The work of statecraft is complex, but these demands are clear.
The people have a right to be informed.
To Sea, or Not To Sea

An Advisor spreads a worn map across the table, and Amina tries her best to feign surprise. Her armies have seized the very earth in her name! There was no city or plot of land that was not under her command.
Where museums hold relics of the dead and reminders of the past, a dedicated shift in curation towards the arts may help inspire the cultured.
Even a small museum enriches culture.
The city is quiet for now, but soon the booming and bellowing melodies of trained singers will call travelers from all over to take in the sounds.
Folk music is the city's culture.
The Opera House sets the tone for all.
Many citizens long dreamed of seeing their city become a hub for economy and trade. Now, the material foundations for this dream are in place.
A leader goes through many growing pains throughout their tenure, and the city stands in testament to their trials and triumphs. Not even experience can predict what comes next.
Strong leadership at home will ease transition.
There must be wars to win and battles to fight abroad.
The city is on the cusp of a new identity, forged by scholars and scientists alike. Its great minds put heads together in the libraries and laboratories, deciding their place among the stars.
History will honor these scholarly works.
The future will reveal the galaxy's mysteries.
There's a new twinkle in the eyes of the city's ambitious youth, who dream of new technology and to see pieces of themselves in the cosmos.
The children will decide the future.
To change a city is to alter its core. Imposing new ideals may come at a cost, but progress cannot be made otherwise.
A united city will work together no matter what.
Soldiers unite under one common goal, that will never change.
A slick, shiny man with a watch chain claims his new invention, the cartamobile, is a real doozy. "It'll sell like hotcakes," he claims, "and no one will need the rail lines any more."
Rail and steam are the city's heart.
Cartamobile sales are booming. They are still out of many consumers' reach, but profits thrive.

The Peacock Throne is the symbol of the empire, from whence all radiance extends. The would-be invaders demand its destruction, infuriating the military commanders. Royal attendants scoff at the insult.
The destruction of the old brings glory to the new.

An engineer has created a vacuum pump, seeking to prove that a void can exist in nature. A philosopher takes offense: if physical vacuums can exist in nature, she says, political vacuums could exist in society, which would be unthinkable, would it not?
Nature and society follow the same order.
Nature's order is distinct from humans'.
In the capital abroad, our representatives make their diplomatic overtures. Behind the closed doors of the cultural outreach office, however, they get to the real business at hand...

The Alliance Française is a stunning building, bringing a spark of French life to a distant shore. But many speculate about France's intentions. What do the officials do once their cultural festivals and diplomatic meetings conclude?
Only the work of diplomacy, truly.
In the city park, there is a special place where anyone may stand, with any cause, and say any thing.
The poll lines stretch for entire city blocks, each waiting face emotional: trepidation, pride, hope. Each person holds fast to the document that describes their right to vote and be counted.
Voting rights depend on land ownership.
The poll lines stretch for entire city blocks, each waiting face emotional: trepidation, pride, hope. Each person holds fast to the document that describes their right to vote and be counted.
Voting rights depend on land ownership.
Radio broadcasts become a crucial avenue for official messaging. The people regularly tune in to hear their leader's messages on the focus of civic work.
Now is the time to rally around work.
As the bog waters drain, something twisted and black tumbles out – a body. Its hair, clothes, skin, fingernails have all turned the color of the bog.

The body found in the bog is put on display under glass, but disparate groups fight to claim it. The historical society sees the body as a collective ancestor to be honored, while forensic scientists consider it a priceless dissection opportunity.
When rubber is treated with sulfur, it hardens. From this new process, tires and tennis balls come bouncing.
The foreign quarter of the capital has become a place of intellectual debate and exchange. Siamese youth parade about in unfamiliar dress, and new words enter into Thai parlance.
Draft these subversives into the army.
Nothing can take away the camaraderie rooted deep in their bones. A bittersweet goodbye, made endurable by the long-awaited promise of a loved one’s embrace.
A battlefield nourishes the soil with iron. Deep within the layers of earth, life begins anew – remnants of the human cost of war feed into an endless cycle of loss and revival.

Among the objects turned up by curious eyes and diligent hands, a tarnished metal eagle surfaces. The missing standard of the legendary lost legion, when the {1_CIVILIZATION_ADJ} people called themselves Roman.
Enshrine it as a symbol of past glory...and future.
Focus on the lessons of the battle instead.

A great slab of rock, a funerary monument to a long-dead woman, has been discovered in a private collection, spirited away during a recent dig. Its possessor sheepishly claims he was moved by the grand declaration of fidelity carved into it.
Enshrine the stone as a public monument.
Commission a story of the couple's enduring love.
The Good Doctor, Restless and Curious
Dr. Rizal stands at the edge of a restless age. There is much to do, to see, to learn.
The Good Doctor, Restless and Curious
Dr. Rizal stands at the edge of a restless age. There is much to do, to see, to learn.
The Good Doctor and Just the Beginning
Dr. Rizal, restless still, returns home once again satisfied by his travels – ever confident in where his curiosity will lead him.
Start a trade route with all other Players.
The Good Doctor, Restless and Curious
Start a trade route with all other Players.
Let others take the first step.

Dr. Rizal finds himself in what locals call a frontier town, far from the stifling embrace of proper society. As he speaks with one prospector, the man's eye shimmers with the glint of gold, or at least its promise.
Ask him about the value of gold.
Ask how far he has gone to find it.

Dr. Rizal stands on the shore of a vast lake, gazing over the water at the uninterrupted horizon. His ears ring with the intense rhythm of drums and the slap of water against the hull of a Baganda war canoe.
The Good Doctor and the French Empire

Dr. Rizal searches for the soul of the French lands. His guide insists that the aristocracy would not know what it means to be French if it bit them in the behind. According to him, they are far too concerned with wars and titles of nobility.
Speak to those who fight in the wars.
The Good Doctor in Meiji Japan
“Our future depends on an openness to new ideas, not just from within but from without," Dr. Rizal's Meiji guide explains. "In matters of defense and of innovation, that openness has served us well."
The Good Doctor in Mexico's Capital

Dr. Rizal works his way through the crowded streets of Mexico’s capital. To one side, he sees a painter working on her latest landscape. To another, a debate rages on the merits of self-determination.
The Good Doctor in Mughal India

Descending a mountain pass, Dr. Rizal and his guide take a moment to take in the view below: A valley of sprawling farmland as far as the eye can see. The doctor can hardly believe that the Mughal empire is so expansive.
How did it get so wealthy?
How did it become so vast?

Dr. Rizal’s guide shows him the delights of the Prussian capital, seeming to take particular pride in its methodical organization. Much of the city is a military garrison, but it is also home to one of the region's most prestigious academies.
"It is lucky you arrived just in time for tea," says Rizal’s host as she fills a cup from an ornate samovar.
Study the culture and ceremony of tea.
Observe the workings of the samovar.
The Good Doctor and the Canals of Siam
In the chaos of a Siamese canal – market-vendors shout from noodle-boats, barges move implacably forward, children play and splash – Dr. Rizal reclines in the shade of a parasol.
Call one of the noodle-boats over.
The Good Doctor and the Qing

Dr Rizal walks a bustling market town, one of many that are blossoming in Qing lands. He can hardly move for all the goods-laden carts, and cabbages roll through the road as he jostles one by mistake.
Study the flow of the market's immense wealth.

A reporter's serialized stories depict working-class struggles inside a canning factory. Its detailed accounts of rats scurrying over conveyor belts and exhausted workers collapsing into rendering vats feel too real to ignore.
Stricter safety standards may preserve lives.
